race.name: Northlander
entries: As with every other race, individuals have their own strengths and weaknesses, but Northlanders all share a few similarities.

entries.name: Age
entries: As other humans, Northlanders reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The violent culture of the Northlanders favors chaotic alignment, as personal strength and the freedom to roam the sea are core parts of their beliefs. Most tend towards neutral alignment, while those that live a life of raid, plunder and enslavement of others revel in evil.

entries.name: Size
entries: Northlanders are tall and strong, most stand between 6 and 7 foot tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Frost Born
entries: You have resistance to cold damage.

entries.name: Mariner
entries: You can hold your breath underwater for twice as long.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with {@item navigator's tools|PHB}.

entries.name: Northern Heart
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use your action to call upon the inner strength that lies into every sons and daughters of the north. Your strength lasts for 1 minute or until you end it as a bonus action. During it, you have advantage on all Strength and Constitution saving throws, and you gain temporary hit points at the start of each of your turns. The temporary hit points equal half your level (rounded up) + your Constitution modifier.
Once you use this trait, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write {@language Common} and Northlander ({@language Illuskan|SCAG}).

race.name: Waelen
entries: At first glance nothing really sets apart a Waelen from another human, however their legacy reveals itself through their strange abilities and quirks.

entries.name: Age
entries: As other humans, waelen reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Waelen tend towards lawful alignments due to their organized society. Those living in the woad-clans are more often chaotic. They have no predilection for good or evil, and most tend toward neutrality.

entries.name: Size
entries: Waelen tend to be tall and slender, with leaner build than most humans. They often reach 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Beast Kinship
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill and add double your proficiency bonus in that skill.

entries.name: Weather Sense
entries: You can accurately predict what the weather will be at your location (no action required) for the next 24 hours. If magic is used to alternate the weather at your location, you immediately sense it.

entries.name: Blood of the Earth
entries: While on the ground in contact with unworked earth or stone, you can spend one Hit Die to heal yourself as a bonus action. Roll the die, add your Constitution modifier, and regain a number of hit points equal to the total (minimum of 1).
Once you use this trait, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

entries.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: You can cast {@spell detect magic} an unlimited number of times with this trait, but you can only sense magic that originated from a fey. Starting at 3rd level, you can also cast {@spell beast bond} with this trait. Once you cast it, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write {@language Common} and {@language Waelen}.

{@i The fierce people known as Northlanders have been amongst the first to set foot on the continent. The isles of their homeland are scoured by strong winds and powerful waves, and also suffer biting, bone-chilling cold for most of the year. In deepest winter, the inlets are choked with ice, and fog lingers late into the day, if it breaks at all. Most wear furs to keep out the cold, and those going to war supplement their protection with thicker hides, and helms lined with wool or fur. They disdain magic and glorify battle, to the point that most communities grow restless when they don't have an enemy to fight.}

entries.name: Warriors and Sailors
entries: Because the Northlanders are good at fighting and sailing, and perfectly willing to attack ships close to their shores, best to be cautious around any Northlander Isles, especially if you haven't been assured of safe passage, and often even then. Still, they are great sailors, thanks to their reliable and sturdy longships and their navigation techniques. The consensus on Northlanders is that they are violent folks who raid and pillage at will and seek to enslave any outlanders they capture on or near their island.

entries.name: A Raider's Life
entries: Northlander society is rhythmed by the seasons, with spring opening the raid season and winter ending it. The truce season, autumn, opens the islands for trade with the rest of the world for a few weeks, as the Northlanders allow foreign ships to land and exchange goods. Aside from the constant economical need for new spoil, be it slaves, resources or treasure, raiding increases a person's stature in Northlander society. A successful raider returns home with wealth and fame, the two most important qualities needed to climb the social ladder.

entries.name: Sons and Daughters of Valkur
entries: Northlanders pay homage to several deities, but they most honor Valkur, a hero-god of their own who exemplifies the qualities their warriors hold most dear: fierceness, cunning, courage, strength and sailing skill. Take care not to question or insult this veneration in their presence. They consider rule over other races and the cities of the coast to be their birthright. Merchants can occasionally trade with northlanders but usually don't risk such a stopover if they can help it. One never knows when the clans are going to be at war, and any ship within sight of the island when it is will be fair prey.

entries.name: Northlander Character
entries: Northlanders are tall, fair-skinned folk with blue or steely gray eyes. Most have blond or raven-black hair, but those who inhabit the extreme northwest have red, or light brown hair.

items.name: Male Names:
items.entry: Agni, Brandr, Eric, Frath, Halvar, Leif, Malcer, Ragnar, Snorri, Ulf

items.name: Female Names:
items.entry: Ama, Eerika, Iona, Kethra, Mara, Saga, Sigrid, Tova, Westra, Ylva

items.name: Surnames/Clans:
items.entry: An Craite, Ard Rhena, Bjarkoy, Dubhghaill, Nibelson, Tordarroch, Völsung, Waegmund

entries.name: Traders and Explorers
entries: Northlanders are commonly seen as pillaging brutes coming on their longboats before retreating to their frozen isles. For a lot of them, this stereotype holds true, but there is more to their culture than raiding. They are also exceptional explorers, craftsmen and shrewd merchants. Their longboat expeditions have reached distant lands that none even heard of, establishing colonies in these faraway territories. When the raiding season comes to a halt, or that a clan decides that trading would be more profitable than war, they establish a permanent or temporary trading outpost, welcoming merchants from across the world. These outposts quickly become centers of transshipment, exchange, and redistribution, where spices, furs and weapon trade are especially welcome.

entries.name: Misty Isles
entries: Cloaked in mists, the rocky cliffs of the Waelen Isles rise high above the surf of the sea, their tops clothed in ancient forests. On the isles live the Waelen, humans ruled by their High King from the royal fortress on the largest isle. The Waelen worship a goddess they call the Earthmother; her druids gather in sacred groves on the islands. Some of these groves hold moonwells, magical pools that the druids say the goddess uses as her windows onto the world. Noted craftsmen, the Waelen enjoy income from their artisans, as well as profiting from their expertise with gold-working. Their culture, craft and wealth are illustrated in the form of fantastic gold torques and other jewelry worn by their nobles. The northern isles are the territory of the Northlanders, who have fought occasional wars with the Waelen in the centuries that the two groups have uneasily shared the islands.

entries.name: Will of the Earthmother
entries: Waelen are deferent to their druids, there exists a rigid social order amongst the tribes. While many matters ostensibly fall to the High Kings and chieftains, in reality, much is governed by the will of the Earthmother's druids, including declarations of war or peace. Blending animism with a pantheon of local and lesser household gods, the Waelen religion is one of the key factors uniting the disparate isles. The importance and political sway of an island, beside its military power and wealth, is measured how much it is "touched by the goddess", with the presence of moonwells. Most rites and celebrations are held at these pools, where sacrifices and offerings are made to please the Earthmother and her spirits.

entries.name: Varied Threats
entries: Living near the perilous forests of the isles, filled with fantastical beasts, and under the constant threat of skirmishes from their Northlander neighbors, the Waelen are hardy people that see the touch of their goddess in many signs and forms. They fight to keep their port towns open so that, farther islands, can receive vital supplies and reinforcements to deal with many and varied threats: dark fey stalking the woods, packs of werefolk worshiping bloody gods, reclusive elves, and worst of all, the ogres serving the vile fomorian giants. The forests of the isles are especially noteworthy, the deeper one goes, the more otherworldly they become, with fey creatures leading travelers astray.

entries.name: Tuatha Dé
entries: The Waelen themselves trace back their ancestors to a mythical tribe, the Tuatha Dé, the tribe of the gods, said to have been great travelers that came to aid and serve the Earthmother. These heroes were all gifted with supernatural gifts of unknown origin that they passed down to their children. To these days, many of them are still revered in household pantheons. As it is often the case, the truth about the Waelen's origin probably lies somewhere in between the myth and tales of the isles.

entries.name: Waelen Character
entries: Waelen tend to have fair skin and light hair colours, ranging from pale blond to vibrant red. They very often have dark blue tattoos made with woad dye. Most would simply consider the Waelen human, but there is more than what meets the eye with the strange islanders.

items.entry: Airic, Dalbeth, Duncan, Ewyn, Liam, Lugh, Manan, Nuada, Tuirenn, Ulaidh

items.name: Female Names:
items.entry: Alane, Danand, Elatha, Keelin, Lesley, Medb, Morrigan, Nessa, Seo, Yseult

items.entry: Domhaill, Eoghain, Lochlann, Mac Bhriain, Mac Oitir, Muireadhaigh, Tyr Teath, Ui Aine

entries.name: Waelen Quirk
entries: Waelen are sometimes called the Fey-Touched by their neighbors, due to the quirks many of them show from birth. After generations of dealing with druidic spirits and mingling with the fey of the forest, magic runs into the blood of each Waelen. The Waelen Quirks table can help make your character more unique and strange. Most Waelen have one to two quirks, and those with strong magic tend to have the strangest ones.

entries.caption: Waelen Quirks
rows: The tip of your fingers is green, and you smell like the morning dew.
Your laugh is sinister and sends shivers down the spine of those who hear it.
When you drink alcohol your eyes glow and emit dim light within 10 feet for 1 minute.
You can hear the ethereal plane and hear voices in the thunder.
You sneeze loudly when a lycanthrope is within 10 feet of you.
Your hair and eyes change color with the seasons.
An unknown entity sometimes whispers through your lips when you are unconscious.
Fey creatures find you incredibly attractive, to the point of obsession.
You appear old or juvenile (50%) under the moonlight.
After touching a beast, you gain a minor and inconsequential physical aspect of the beast (feathers, fangs, tail...) until your next short or long rest.

reward.name: Soul Torment
entries: Soul Torment is a curse that afflicts a creature whose soul is being slowly torn apart by vile magic. If the target dies out of {@condition exhaustion}, the target's soul is destroyed and ceases to exist, preventing any use of resurrection magic on the creature. The curse lasts until removed by the {@spell greater restoration} spell or other magic.

items: For every 24 hours that elapse, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.
While cursed, the creature is unable to sleep and the curse prevents the target from gaining any benefit from resting.
The creature's emotions become cold and numb; it gains advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} but disadvantage on Wisdom and Charisma checks.

item.name: Bewitching Wine
entries: This wine, distilled from the blood of a {@creature night mother|BoBH} vampire, is usually kept in a superbly adorned decanter. If drank by a living creature, the creature instantly falls {@condition unconscious} for 8 hours and age by {@dice 1d4} years. During its sleep the creature has the most vivid erotic dreams, more realistic than life and fulfilling all its darkest fantasies. When it wakes up, the creature remembers the dreams perfectly and must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, gaining a level of {@condition exhaustion} on failure.

entries.name: Curse
entries: The dreams induced by the wine are so intense that reality pales to compare, letting the cursed creature eternally unsatisfied. Until the curse is removed the creature gains a form of indefinite madness "I'll do everything I can to relive these dreams again".

item.name: Deep Lead Bomb
entries: As an action, a character can throw a bomb at a point up to 30 feet away. Each creature within 10 feet of an exploding deep lead bomb must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 17 ({@dice 5d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Each creature that takes any of this damage must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the creature can't maintain {@status concentration} on a spell or any other effect that requires {@status concentration}. The {@condition poisoned} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

item.name: Deep Lead Shackles
entries: These sturdy shackles are made of an alloy of deep lead and iron. A character can use an action to place these shackles on an {@condition incapacitated} Small or Medium creature. In addition to serving as mundane manacles, the shackles prevent a creature bound by them from {@action cast a spell|PHB|casting any spell}. Escaping the shackles requires a successful {@dc 25} Dexterity check. Breaking them requires a successful {@dc 25} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. Each set of shackles comes with one key. Without the key, a creature proficient with {@item thieves' tools|PHB} can pick the shackles' lock with a successful {@dc 20} Dexterity check. Shackles have 30 hit points.

item.name: Elder Sign
entries: An elder sign is a seal humming with ancient power that wards against aberrations. Also called a cerulean sign, it is usually crafted in soapstone and covered with a complex pattern of runes and sigils, with a cerulean blue central fivepointed star that has been distorted along its lines and contains an eye-flame symbol in its center. The elder signs were used to seal off those places where the Great Old Ones were imprisoned or where they had a chance of breaking through in force to the Material Plane. The techniques used to create these seals have been long lost.

entries.name: Elder Ward
entries: While the elder sign is on your person, you have advantage on saving throws against spells. You also can't be {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, or possessed by aberrations.

entries.name: Elder Magic
entries: The elder sign has 5 charges. While you hold it, you can use an action to cast one of the following spells (save {@dc 18}) from it: {@spell banishment} (expends 1 charge) or {@spell greater restoration} (expends 2 charges).

Alternatively, you can use an action to place the elder sign at a location to ward off teleportation and planar travel (expends 5 charges). The sign projects an {@condition invisible} field in a 2-mile radius. The field lasts until someone picks up the sign. It even lasts after your attunement to the sign ends, as long as it remains undisturbed. This field blocks all forms of conjuration magic and any other effect that involves teleportation and extradimensional or interplanar travel.
The elder sign regains 1 expended charge daily at dawn.

item.name: Griffin Claw
entries: This claw is coming from the wing of a griffin. When you hold it in your hand you can use an action to cast the {@condition detect poison and disease} spell for 1 hour at will and gain resistance to poison damage and immunity to the {@condition poisoned} condition for the same duration. The claw turns black when it detects poison or disease. After the hour passes the claw loses all magic properties.

item.name: Hairlock Charm
entries: This charm made of intertwined leanan hairs carries the muse's magic. When you hold it in your hand, you can use an action to gain a supernatural charm of the GM 's choice. See chapter 7 of the Dungeon Master's Guide for more information on supernatural charms. After it is used, the charm loses all magic properties.

item.name: Kikimore Oil
entries: One bottle of oil is enough to cover the ground in a 20-foot square, lasting for 24 hours, unless washed away by water prematurely. Once applied to a surface the oil can have one of the following effect, chosen at its creation:

items: {@i Threat:} A kikimore that enters the area or ends its turn there must succeed on a {@dc 12} Intelligence saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until it leaves the area.

{@i Food:} When a kikimore comes within 60 feet of the area, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 12} Intelligence saving throw or use its movement on each of its turns to enter the area. When the creature has done so, it can't willingly move away from the area. If an affected creature takes damages or is otherwise harmed, the affected creature can make an Intelligence saving throw to end the effect on itself.

item.name: Kikimore Venom
entries: This poison must be harvested from a dead or {@condition incapacitated} kikimore warrior. A creature subjected to this poison must make on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 13 ({@dice 2d12}) poison damage and is {@condition poisoned}. The {@condition poisoned} creature must repeat the saving throw every 24 hours, taking 13 ({@dice 2d12}) poison damage on a failed save. Until this poison ends, the damage the poison deals can't be healed by any means. The poison lasts until it is cured by a {@spell lesser restoration} spell or similar magic.

item.name: Lead Symphonium
entries: This cumbersome music box is crafted in deep lead, it is a Small object weighing 55 pounds. A character must be proficient with box-shaped instruments to use this music box. A character can use an action to play the symphonium, creating a loud and dissonant grinding melody. An {@spell antimagic field} is created in a 20-foot radius sphere centered on the music box and moving with it until the start of the character's next turn.
When the box' property has been used for a total of 10 minutes, it is out of tune and ceases to function until repaired by a creature knowing the secret of its creation.

item.name: Masterpiece
entries: A masterpiece can take many forms and shapes, as many as there is ways to express art. If you are within 5 feet of the masterpiece, you can use an action to speak its command word and activate it. It remains activated until you use an action to speak the command word again. Any creature other than you using an action to interact adequately with the masterpiece must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the creature gains the ideal of the masterpiece's author, which overrides any opposing ideal. At the end of each long rest, the influenced creature can repeat the saving throw. On a successful saving throw, the creature loses the new ideal. If a creature successfully saves against the effect, it is immune to the influence of the masterpiece. Casting the {@spell dispel evil and good} spell on the creature also removes the new ideal.

item.name: Nullus Box
entries: Crafted in deep lead and iron, this box is especially made to contain cursed or possessed objects but works on all magical item. It can contain one Small or Medium item, but larger variant exists. While inside the box a magic item that isn't an artifact has its magical properties suppressed. After {@dice 1d12} consecutive months inside the box, the item loses all its properties and is no longer magical. If an item remains in the box for more than 24 hours and is removed before losing its properties, an effect is produced immediately upon the box opening. The DM can choose an effect from the following table, determine it randomly, or create an effect.

rows: The item and the box are destroyed and a {@spell gate} to a random plane of existence opens. The {@spell gate} originates from the location of the box. Any creature within 10 feet of the {@spell gate} is sucked through it to a random location on the plane. The {@spell gate} then closes. The {@spell gate} is one-way only and can't be reopened.
Nothing happens.

Deep lead dust fills the air. Each creature within 30 feet of the box must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the creature can't maintain {@status concentration} on a spell or any other effect that requires {@status concentration}.
A {@dice 2d6 x 10} foot-radius sphere centered on the box becomes a dead magic zone (similar to an {@spell antimagic field}) for {@dice 1d4} hours.

A {@dice 2d6 x 10} foot-radius sphere centered on the box becomes a wild magic zone (roll on the {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB} table in the Player's Handbook whenever a spell is cast within the zone) for {@dice 1d4} hours.

A surge of magical energy is unleashed. Each creature within 30 feet of the box must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 55 {@dice (10d10)} force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The item and the box are destroyed.

item.name: Potion of Dreamsight
entries: Prepared by a {@creature druid} or {@creature leathdhia|BoBH} with the sacred water of a moonwell and poppy tears, this brew is generally used to receive a vision quest. It is also known to be strongly hallucinogenic. For 1 hour after you drink this potion, you can see {@condition invisible} creatures and objects as if they were visible, and you can see into the Ethereal Plane. When the effect ends, you must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or gain a random form of {@table long-term madness|DMG} {@homebrew |(roll on the Long-Term Madness table on page 260 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG})}.
There is a {@chance 25|25 percent} chance that you benefit from the spell {@spell commune} while under the influence this madness.

item.name: Restless Eye
entries: This fleshy, evil-looking eye is the Third Eye of a fallen morvudd or chort. The eye merges with your forehead, blinking and staring independently from your eyes. The eye has 3 charges, and it regains {@dice 1d3} expended charges daily at dawn. You can use an action to expend 1 of its charges to cast the {@spell eyebite} spell at {@dc 15} from it. Additionally you gain proficiency with the Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) skill or gain advantage on this roll if you are already proficient.

entries.name: Curse
entries: The eye is cursed: a fact that is revealed only when an identify spell is cast on the eye or you attune to it. Attuning to the eye curses you until you are targeted by the {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic; extracting the eye a dangerous operation fails to end the curse. While cursed, if you have a neutral or good alignment, each long rest you must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw, suffering from a shortterm madness (p. 259 of the Dungeon Master Manual) on a failed save. If the save fails by 5 or more, you also suffer from a long-term madness. The short-term and long-term madnesses can be ended with the {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic.

item.name: Solais
entries: The story of the misty isles and its people is beautiful and bloody, entwined with the fate of its primary inhabitants, the Waelen and the fey folks. Although now the two are closely connected, it wasn't always so. In bygone times, cruel fey emerged from the Feywild and enslaved most of the Waelen, toying with them for their sick pleasure and amusement.

Desperate, the Waelen begged for the goddess 'help, her answer came as a mighty blade, held out of the waters of the moonwell {@i Fharraige Fáil} by a female hand. This blade was Solais, the archfey-slayer, and even nowadays the silvery handprint of the goddess is still visible on its grip. Armed with the artifact, a chosen of the Waelen, a warrior named Nuadha, ventured into the Feywild and defeated the archfey responsible for the enslavement of his people.

Returning victorious, Nuadha rallied the isles and was soon crowned the first Antler-King. Now centuries later, Solais was lost and stolen on more than a few occasions, but always recovered, for its people would move mountains for it. It is still passed down from High King to High King, symbol of the rightful ruler and chosen of the goddess.

entries.name: Magic Weapon
entries: Solais is a magic weapon that grants a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with it.

entries.name: Random Properties
entries: The Sword of Kas has the following random properties:

items: 1 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Beneficial Properties|dmg|minor beneficial property}
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Major Beneficial Properties|dmg|major beneficial property}
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Detrimental Properties|dmg|minor detrimental property}

entries.name: Archfey-Slayer
entries: The sword deals an extra {@dice 2d10} force damage to fey. If the target has 50 hit points or fewer after taking this damage, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or be killed. A fey killed by the sword cannot be revived by anything short of divine intervention or the {@spell wish} spell.

entries.name: Steel Wind Strike
entries: If you are holding the sword, you can use your action to cast the {@spell steel wind strike|XGE} spell from it. When you make the spell's attacks, use your melee weapon attack with Solais. You can't use this property again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Blessing of the Earthmother
entries: If you are attuned to the sword and have been accepted by the Earthmother as the wielder of the blade, you gain the following benefits.

items: You cannot be {@condition charmed}.
You have advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks to determine the nature of an illusion.
You can stand on and move across any liquid surface as if it were solid ground.

entries.name: Planar Disruption.
entries: You can use an action to slash a planar portal with the sword, such as that created by the {@spell gate} spell, or an extradimensional space, such as that within a {@item portable hole|DMG}. Make a {@dc 15} ability check using your spellcasting ability (if any). On a successful check, the portal is shut down for {@dice 1d10} days. Once Solais has closed a portal, it can't do so again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Cleanse Water
entries: You can use an action to immerse the blade of the sword into water. You turn up to 50 gallons of waters into clean water. In addition, a creature that drinks at least half a gallon of cleansed water within the next hour benefits from the {@spell lesser restoration} spell and its hit point maximum also increases by {@dice 2d10}, and it gains the same number of hit points. These benefits last for 24 hours. You can't use this property again until the next dawn.

item.name: Stone to Flesh Ointment
entries: The eggs of a greater cockatrice are known to be one of the few remedies besides magic that can cure {@condition petrified|PHB|petrification}. Combined with other rare ingredients and plants, it can be used to make a ointment that will return a creature to its true form.

A character that has proficiency with {@item Alchemist's Supplies|PHB|Alchemist's Tools} or {@item Herbalism Kit|PHB}, and access to the proper equipment, can prepare an ointment with the great cockatrice egg. The ointment has a value of 200gp when it comes to crafting (see crafting rules p.187 of the Player's Handbook). Once applied to the skin of the {@condition petrified} creature, the ointment will be turning it back to flesh in an hour.

item.name: The Emerald Tablet
item.reqAttune: by a creature proficient with alchemist's supplies
entries: Among the many treatises of alchemy, none is more famous than the Emerald Tablet, a text akin for alchemists to the {@item Book of Vile Darkness} or the {@item Book of Exalted Deeds}, containing limitless scientific potential. Those that lay their hands on the mystical Emerald Tablet understand that alchemy isn't limited to the physical world, but encompasses all levels of reality, matter, shape, and form. The tablet unveils the universal principles of growth and the fluidity of change in all things. Made of pure emerald, its surface is carved with alchemical equations that only practitioners can understand. The tablet can be read from all directions and angles, seemingly revealing new texts based on its orientation, a puzzling property of its form.

It is said to contain infinite alchemical knowledge, from the secret to create a Philosopher's Stone, how to achieve true chrysopoeia or how to brew the elixir of immortality. The tablet has been lost and rediscovered countless times through the ages, always sparking a new age of discovery and scientific achievements when found. Many attempts have been made to copy its formulas, and some have had some limited successes in doing so, but the most difficult formulas always seem to end-up incorrect, somehow requiring the tablet's possession to be performed.

An attuned creature must spend 80 hours reading and studying the tablet to digest its contents and gain its benefits. Other creatures can read the carvings but glean no deeper meaning and reap no benefits. Benefits granted by the Emerald Tablet last only as long as you have the tablet in your possession. If you lose possession of the tablet, you lose all the benefits that it grants.

entries.name: Random Properties
entries: The Emerald Tablet has the following random properties:

items: 1 {@table Artifact Properties; Major Beneficial Properties|dmg|major beneficial properties}
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Major Detrimental Properties|dmg|major detrimental properties}

entries.name: Increased Intelligence
entries: After you spend the requisite amount of time reading and studying the tablet, your Intelligence score increases by 2, to a maximum of 24. You can't gain this benefit from the tablet more than once.

entries.name: Inner Alchemy
entries: The numerical effects and duration of potions you drink are doubled. If a potion has nothing to double in this way, it works normally.

entries.name: Marvelous Alchemist
entries: You gain intuitive knowledge of alchemy. You can instantly identify any poison, potion, or oil you come across. You gain advantage on ability checks using {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB} and double your proficiency bonus with them.

Additionally, you can use an {@item alchemy jug} you possess to create a potion of your choice during a short rest. Unless drunk within 24 hours, the potion loses its magical properties. The tablet can't be used this way again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Destroying the Tablet
entries: The tablet holds the mean of its own destruction. The tablet is destroyed if it is submerged in alkahest acid for 24 hours. Alkahest is a complex acid, requiring many rare and costly components, that can only be created by a creature attuned to the tablet.

item.name: Unicorn Salts
entries: While wearing the pouch around your neck you are hidden from divination magic from fey creatures of evil alignment. You can't be targeted by such magic or perceived through magical scrying sensors. A fey creature of evil alignment who targets you with an attack or a harmful spell must first make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature must choose a new target or lose the attack or spell. This effect doesn't protect you from area effects, such as the explosion of a {@spell fireball}. You are immune to the memory loss induced by the spectral hunt and the Feywild.

item.name: Unicorn Salts
entries: Prepared by a druid or leathdhia with the sacred water of a moonwell and poppy tears, this brew is generally used to receive a vision quest. It is also known to be strongly hallucinogenic. For 1 hour after you drink this potion, you can see invisible creatures and objects as if they were visible, and you can see into the Ethereal Plane. When the effect ends, you must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or gain a random form of long-term madness (roll on the {@table Long-Term Madness|DMG} table on page 260 of the Dungeon Master's Guide). There is a 25 percent chance that you benefit from the spell {@spell commune} while under the influence this madness.

item.name: Witch-catcher
entries: Coming as a pocket watch, compass or even a pendulum, this small device clearly reacts when magic is within 5 feet of it. It detects active spells, magical items or places that have been magically consecrated or desecrated.

itemGroup.name: Oathblade
entries: Oathblades are mystic silver swords that appeared in past eras, floating above the waters of the moonwells, a gift from the goddess in times of need. Each Oathblade is unique, once gifted to defeat a particular foe. An oathblade is a silvered magic weapon.

entries.name: Calhain (rare)
entries: When you reduce a hostile creature to 0 hit points with this weapon, the next attack that hits with this weapon inflict extra damage of the weapon's type equal to the number of Hit Dice of the slain creature.

entries.name: Dyrn (rare)
entries: When you reduce a hostile creature to 0 hit points with this weapon, you turn invisible until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Eala (rare)
entries: While attuned to this weapon and holding the sword, whenever you take the {@action Dodge} action you gain a +2 bonus to AC. If a melee weapon attack hits you while dodging, you can use your reaction to spend one Hit Die to reduce the damage. Roll the die, add your Dexterity modifier, and reduce the damage by a number equal to the total (minimum of 1).

entries.name: Fragarach (rare)
entries: When attacking underwater with this weapon, you do not have disadvantage on the attack roll. Additionally, while attuned to it, you can breathe underwater.

entries.name: Moralt (rare)
entries: When you hit a conjured creature with this weapon, the creature takes an extra {@damage 2d6} damage of the weapon's type. Also, each time a creature takes the extra damage, the creature that conjured it takes the same amount of damage. For the purpose of this weapon, "conjured creature" refers to any creature that was called by a conjuration spell, such as the {@spell conjure elemental} spell, or a per Day use feature, such as the Summon Demon from a {@creature drow mage|MM|drow}.

entries.name: Muhrdem (very rare)
entries: The weapon scores a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20 and when you hit a creature with the weapon, the target can't regain hit points until the start of your next turn.

magicvariant.name: Deep Lead Ammunition
entries: Deep lead is seldomly used to craft armors, for the intense discomfort felt by the wearer outweigh the benefits it provides, however the metal is used for weapons.

Melee weapons and ammunition made of or coated with deep lead are unusually effective against spellcasters, disrupting their {@status concentration}. Whenever a creature takes damage from a deep lead weapon or piece of ammunition and is concentrating on a spell, it has disadvantage on the saving throw it makes to maintain its {@status concentration}.
The deep lead version of a melee weapon or of ten pieces of ammunition costs 300 gp more than the normal version, whether the weapon or ammunition is made of the metal or coated with it.

You can use an action to cause the blade to radiate eldritch energy, absorbing light and warping reality around it until an attack using this weapon hits a creature. That creature must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or contract the {@disease Warp Touch|BoBH} disease. The sword can't be used this way again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Curse
entries: If the sword isn't used to infect a creature with the {@disease Warp Touch|BoBH} within 1 minute of being drawn from its scabbard, its wielder must make a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw. On a successful save, the wielder takes {@damage 3d6} psychic damage. On a failed save, the wielder is dominated by the sword, as if by the {@spell dominate monster} spell, and the sword demands that it is used to spread the {@disease Warp Touch|BoBH}. The spell effect ends when the sword's demand is met.

entries.name: Deep Lead
entries: Lead as a metal is known to be a natural counter to magic. The thinnest sheet of lead can block the most powerful of divination, and it is often used as a mean to protect against magical prying. A purer form of lead, called deep lead or sometimes dimeritium, exists. It is a silvery metal with a hint of blue found only rarely in mineral veins. Deep lead is highly toxic, and those frequently exposed to it regularly experience migraines, respiratory diseases or even seizures. These effects are amplified for magical creatures and spellcasters that will instantly feel nauseous in its presence and intense physical pain at its contact. Witch Hunters rely heavily on deep lead and have integrated in their arsenal several devices based on that metal to face their most dangerous enemy: spellcasters.

language.name: Northlander
entries: {@note As {@language Illuskan|SCAG}}

trait.name: Alchemic Blood
entries: When the alkahzir takes damage of any type but psychic, each creature within 5 feet of the alkazir takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) acid damage.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the alkahzir fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Phenomenal Mithridatism
entries: After taking damage, the alkahzir gains immunity to damage of that type, except psychic damage, until the start of its next turn. If the alkahzir's takes extra damage from the Philosopher's Stone trait, this trait doesn't function until the start of the alkahzir's next turn.

trait.name: Philosopher's Stone
entries: Once per round when the alkahzir is attacked by a creature, the attacker can target the philosopher's stone trapped in it. The attacker has disadvantage on the attack roll. On a hit, the attack deals an extra 11 ({@dice 2d10}) damage to the alkahzir, and the alkahzir gains an additional action on its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The alkahzir makes two alkahest dissolution attacks.

action.name: Debilitate
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw or be debilitated by disease. The diseased creature can't regain hit points, and has disadvantage on Constitution saving throws.

action.name: Alkahest Dissolution
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 14} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}66 ({@damage 12d10}) acid damage. At the start of each of its turns, the target must make a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw, taking 33 ({@damage 6d10}) acid damage on a failure or ending the recurring acid damage on a success. A lesser restoration spell cast on the target also ends the recurring acid damage.

action.name: Shape Materia
entries: The alkahzir performs a special alchemical procedure on one object composed entirely of wood, stone, or metal, transforming it into a different one of those materials. For each round it spends performing the procedure, it can transform 2 cubic foot of material, up to a 20-foot cube. If it concentrates on this effect for 1 minute, (as if it were concentrating on a spell), the transformation becomes permanent, otherwise the material reverts instantly to its original substance.

action.name: Aetheric Blaze {@recharge 5}
entries: The alkahzir agitates matter in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) fire damage and 36 ({@damage 8d8}) force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Debilitate
entries: The alkahzir makes one debilitate attack.

legendary.name: Azoth Transitory Shape (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The alkahzir targets one creature it can see within 60 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw or be transformed for 1 minute into a gaseous, liquid, or solid form (the alkahzir's choice), unless it is a shapechanger. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the effect lasts for the full duration, the transformation becomes permanent. Only a wish spell can reverse the permanent transformation.

While transformed, the creature can't take any actions, speak, or manipulate objects. A creature's statistics, other than its speed, are unchanged. Anything it is wearing transforms with it, but nothing it is carrying does. It is immune to all nonmagical damage. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

In gaseous form, the target is weightless, has a flying speed of 20 feet, can hover, and can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. In addition, if air can pass through a space, the creature can do so without squeezing, and it can't pass through water.

In liquid form, the target's walking speed becomes 0, it has a swimming speed of 20 feet, and it can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can breathe air and water and can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.
In solid form, the target is {@condition petrified}.

legendary.name: Artificial Life (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: The alkahzir touches the corpse of a Medium humanoid within 5 feet of it, causing it to become a flesh golem (see the Monster Manual for its stat block) for 1 hour. If the alkahzir gives the golem no commands, it does nothing but follow the alkahzir and take the Dodge action.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The alp's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). The alp can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: If the vampire isn't in sunlight, it can use its action to polymorph into a Medium female humanoid or back into its true form. While in humanoid form, its statistics, are the same. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Elusive
entries: Attack rolls made against the vampire have disadvantage unless the vampire is {@condition incapacitated} or {@condition restrained}. No attack roll has advantage against the vampire while it isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Vampire Weaknesses
entries: The vampire has the following flaws:

{@i Blood Addiction.} If the temptation for blood is strong (an open wound, the smell of blood), the vampire has disadvantage on blood frenzy saving throws. In the presence of the blood of a virgin the vampire fails automatically.
{@i Sunlight Hypersensitivity} The vampire takes 20 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vampire makes three melee attacks, only one of which can be a bite attack.

action.name: Claws (Vampire Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 6}) slashing damage. Instead of dealing damage, the vampire can grapple the target (escape {@dc 14}).

action.name: Bite (Vampire Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature that is {@condition grappled} by the vampire, {@condition incapacitated} or {@condition restrained}. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d6 + 6}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken, and the vampire regains hit points equal to that amount. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

variant.name: Deathwail Alp
entries: A deathwail alp has a challenge rating of 8 (3,900 XP) and the following additional action options:

entries.name: Legendary Actions
entries: The alp can take 2 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The alp regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

entries.name: Hide
entries: The vampire makes a Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check.

entries.name: Rush
entries: The vampire may move up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks and makes a claws attack.

entries.name: Deathwail (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The vampire screams in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and take 18 ({@damage 4d8}) thunder damage. On a successful save, the creature takes only half the damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.

legendary.name: Rush
